Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: An Ontology-Based System for Querying Life in a Post-Taxonomic Age
Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving our understanding of life, whether the biology of individual species such as our own, or the mechanisms and processes governing biodiversity at large, critically depends on integrating, querying, and aggregating biological data from many different organisms. To this day, the most fundamental and common way to accomplish this relies on organism names, making these one of the pillars of querying and managing our biological knowledge and data. However, the traditionally used names for organisms and groups of organisms, which are based in Linnaean nomenclature, suffer from two major limitations to their usefulness when it comes to integrating and communicating data. First, because they are simple text-strings, the meaning intended by those who coin a name and those who apply it is inaccessible to machines. As a result, exactly which organism a name is or is not meant to include is often ambiguous, and names are therefore often applied inconsistently. Second, there are many groups of organisms that do not yet and may never have a Linnaean name, but for which molecular or macroscopic characteristics have been discovered that constitute valuable biological knowledge. This project aims to address these issues by generating a mechanism, called phyloreferencing, that allows referring to any group of organisms of shared evolutionary descent by a machine-interpretable definition of the unique pattern of descent that distinguishes the group from all others. This project builds on more than a decade's worth of theoretical and applied research into phylogenetic taxonomy. With the recent synthesis and continuous update of a universal phylogenetic Tree of Life, phyloreferences will have immediate and broad practical applications for communicating, integrating, and querying biological data across the Tree of Life. In contrast to authoritative nomenclatural naming, the goal for phyloreferences is that users can construct them instantly for any group of shared evolutionary descent for which they wish to communicate discoveries. In addition to developing the phyloreferencing standard and supporting tools, this project also aims to create classroom-ready teaching materials and curricula for training biology students in the theoretical underpinnings and practical applications of phylogenetic nomenclature.

The phyloreferencing mechanism that this project will develop uses standards and tools developed for the Web, specifically the Web Ontology Language (OWL), ontologies, and machine reasoning. Specifically, this work aims to develop phyloreferences as OWL class expressions consisting of sufficient and necessary conditions, which machine reasoners can use to identify subclasses and class instances. Ontology and reasoning technologies have already shown their power for biological knowledge integration and discovery and are increasingly being adopted for evolutionary research as well. As part of this project, a specification for constructing and computing with phyloreferences within an ontological framework will be researched, implemented, and tested. Phyloreferences will be designed with the goal that any element, whether node, branch, or clades, on the Tree of Life can be referenced in a way that is unambiguous and has fully computable semantics defined by patterns of evolutionary relatedness. The main objectives of this research include creating a formal specification for phyloreference and phylogeny encoding and reasoning in OWL; ascertaining correctness of the specification using small-scale tests verifiable by domain experts; and finally scaling the approach to a large-scale biodiversity data resource navigation proof-of-concept application. Specifically phyloreferences will be developed and integrated into Open Tree of Life, ARBOR and projects newly funded by the Genealogy of Life program. Results of the project will be available at http://www.phyloref.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integrating the vast amount of biodiversity data available from disparate sources and endeavors in new ways and at large scale holds great promise for biological discovery. One of the most common variables for linking biodiversity data is the taxon. However, the prevailing mechanism by which this is done, namely by Linnaean taxon names, suffers from a number of intrinsic limitations, especially in the context of the frequent reliance on large-scale computation. Chiefly, the taxon concepts to which Linnaean taxon names point are frequently inconsistent and change over time, leading to rampant ambiguity about their semantics. Computational disambiguation is often impossible, because Linnaean names and even published taxon concepts lack machine-accessible semantics. Also, for integration with the Tree of Life-scale phylogenies that are available today, the repurposing of Linnaean names, which point to concepts not created from phylogenetic context, is often impossible to be based on verifiably matching semantics. As a result, integrating data by Linnaean taxon names frequently lacks full computational reproducibility. As another major limitation, many groups of organisms with interesting scientific properties and data to report about them exist, yet do not have and may never have a Linnaean name, rendering those data unavailable if reuse and repurposing relies on Linnaean taxon names.  Phylogenetic clade definitions, which define monophyletic groups based on shared evolutionary ancestry, at a theoretical level possess all the properties necessary to overcome these challenges, including unambiguous formalizable semantics and designating tree-native taxon concepts. The focus of this project, and its intellectual merit was to develop a system through which phylogenetic clade definitions in the form of natural language text, as which they are published ?in the wild?, can be digitized to what we call phyloreferences, which we define as the representation of phylogenetic clade definitions in a well-structured machine-readable form with semantics made fully machine-interpretable through the use of ontologies and formal logic. Phyloreferences generated by the system were to be computationally and thus reproducibly resolvable to a node on a given phylogenetic tree, if, and only if, there is a node on the tree matching the semantics of the clade definition represented by the phyloreference.

In pursuit of these goals, this project has produced the following outcomes.  First, based on researching clade definitions published both in adherence to the PhyloCode (the nomenclatural code for phylogenetic clade names) and without, we developed Phyx, a well-structured data model and exchange format for phyloreferences that maintains strong ties to ontology-defined semantics. The format, and supporting software library we created (phyx.js), were designed to meet a number of requirements to promote its as foundational infrastructure, including automatic validation for syntactic and semantic correctness, strong support across scientific programming languages, and human readability. Second, we developed OWL ontologies, in particular the Phyloreferencing Ontology and the Taxon Concept and Name Ontology, to define classes and properties for reasoning with the semantics of phyloreferences, clades, taxon concepts, and the components of phylogenetic trees. We also developed algorithms for enumerating logic definitions for phyloreferences for all possible tree topologies. Third, we developed Klados, a browser-based phyloreference curation tool providing an interactive user-interface for digitizing phylogenetic clade definitions into phyloreferences, or authoring them from scratch. The tool supports collection of the various data and metadata comprising a phyloreference, including a reference phylogeny; ensures compliance with the Phyx data model and exchange format; and can output phyloreferences as classes with logic definitions together with reference phylogenies as an OWL2 ontology. We also developed a machine reasoning web-service for tools such as Klados to test and visualize which nodes on a reference phylogeny or the Open Tree of Life match the logic definition of a phyloreference. Fourth, to enable digitization of a large collection of community-vetted clade definitions with taxonomic and scientific significance into a reusable Clade Ontology, we developed a pipeline for importing records from RegNum, the official registration database of phylogenetic clade definitions and names for the PhyloCode and its inaugural PhyloNym volume. The workflow uses Klados to curate RegNum records into phyloreferences, which are then converted into an OWL2 ontology, the Clade Ontology. Fifth, we created comprehensive mechanisms for subjecting all major software components and their outputs to automatic testing so that changes in software and ontologies do not silently break the syntactic or semantic correctness of phyloreferences. All software source code, ontologies, and data standards are openly available on GitHub under open content licenses. Several manuscripts describing the products are pending publication or in preparation.

As part of promoting broader impacts of this work, a multifaceted exhibit was developed that is now showcased in the Florida Museum of Natural History?s Explore Research exhibition space. An accompanying openly available online video presentation describes the relevance of this work to biodiversity science.
